title: 109_s1096
content: The Act may be cited as the "Musconetcong Wild and Scenic Rivers Act". Congress finds that the Secretary of the Interior is studying the Musconetcong River in New Jersey for inclusion in the Wild and Scenic Rivers System. The Musconetcong Wild and Scenic River Study Task Force has prepared a management plan for the area to protect its values. Thirteen municipalities and three counties along the river have passed resolutions supporting its designation. Thirteen municipalities and three counties along the Musconetcong River in New Jersey have passed resolutions supporting the river's designation as a component of the Wild and Scenic Rivers System. They express support for the Musconetcong River Management Plan and agree to implement its goals. The text chunk "SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS." is a concise statement defining terms within a specific context. In this Act, the term "additional river segment" refers to a 4.3-mile section of the Musconetcong River. The term "management plan" is the plan created by various organizations in 2003 to protect the river's values and resources. The term "river segment" refers to any part of the Musconetcong River in New Jersey. The Musconetcong River segment in New Jersey is designated as a scenic or recreational river by the Wild and Scenic Rivers Act. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. The Musconetcong River in New Jersey is designated as a scenic river for a 3.5-mile segment and a recreational river for a 20.7-mile segment by the Wild and Scenic Rivers Act. The designated river segments will be administered by the Secretary of the Interior and will not be part of the National Park System. SEC. 5. MANAGEMENT. The Secretary shall manage the river segments in accordance with the management plan, which satisfies the requirements for a comprehensive management plan under the Wild and Scenic Rivers Act. The Secretary will assess proposed water resource projects based on their consistency with the management plan. The Secretary may provide technical assistance, staff support, and funding for the implementation of the management plan. Cooperation with various agencies, including the Musconetcong River Management Committee, Musconetcong Watershed Association, Heritage Conservancy, National Park Service, and New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection, is required for managing river segments. Cooperative agreements must align with the management plan and may include financial provisions. The Secretary may provide assistance for the protection, conservation, and enhancement of river segments, including financial aid. Planning and financial assistance can be given to local municipalities and nonprofit organizations for implementing actions to protect natural and historic resources. Zoning ordinances of municipalities bordering the segments will meet the standards of the Wild and Scenic Rivers Act after adopting recommendations from the management plan. Congress acknowledges the need for designating an additional river segment. Congress finds that the additional river segment may be designated as a recreational river if there is adequate local support. If the Secretary determines sufficient support, the segment will be designated and administered according to the Wild and Scenic Rivers Act. The Secretary will consider local government preferences in determining adequate local support for designating the additional river segment. Appropriations are authorized for carrying out the Act and its amendments. The curr_chunk is about the roles of the Speaker of the House of Representatives and the Vice President of the United States as President of the Senate.
